citation.article-title: Helicobacter canadensis sp. nov. isolated from humans with diarrhea as an example of an emerging pathogen.

p.s: Description of Helicobacter canadensis sp. nov.
Helicobacter canadensis (relating to the country of original isolation)
Cells are slender, curved to spiral rods (0.3 by 1.5 to 4 μm), which have one to three spirals.
The bacterium is gram negative and nonsporulating; it is motile by means of nonsheathed, single unipolar or bipolar flagella.
Cultures grown on solid agar media appear as spreading layers.
Cells exhibit microaerobic but not aerobic or anaerobic growth.
The bacteria are urease, alkaline phosphatase, and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase negative but catalase and oxidase positive.
The organism hydrolyzes indoxyl acetate, and some strains reduce nitrate to nitrite.
Cells are resistent to nalidixic acid and cephalothin.
Bacteria have been isolated from the feces of diarrheic humans.
The type strain is NLEP-16143 (MIT 98-5491) (5 ATCC 700968).
